filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of twenty-seven water color drawings produced by Blake between 1775 and c. 1790. Blake’s activities as a water colorist from the mid-1770s through the next decade reveal his increasing skills in that medium, ranging from apprentice work to original compositions exhibited at the Royal Academy. Assignments from his engraving instructor, James Basire, included the precise copying of tomb monuments in Westminster Abbey (Objects 1-5). These water colors were later engraved, probably with Blake’s assistance, as illustrations for Joseph Ayloffe’s Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey (1780), republished in volume 2 of the Society of Antiquaries’ Vetusta Monumenta (c. 1789). This early contact with Gothic art profoundly affected Blake’s later work as an artist and his writings on the history of art. Shortly after his release from apprenticeship in 1779, Blake began to develop a series of designs picturing major events in the history of England (Objects 7-12). He exhibited one of these, The Death of Earl Goodwin (Object 9) or a more finished version of the design, at the Royal Academy in 1780. This group of pictures may have culminated in “The History of England, a small book of Engravings,” advertised in Blake’s prospectus To the Public in October 1793. Unfortunately, no copy of that work has ever been recorded. Blake developed at least one work in this series, Pestilence, Probably the Great Plague of London (Object 12), into a slightly larger and more finished water color (Object 14). Lear and Cordelia was probably executed as part of the history of England series but is presented in the Archive under Water Color Drawings, Illustrations to Shakespeare. Blake’s early water colors include several designs with biblical subjects (Objects 6, 13, 15, 18, 20-23, 27). The most highly finished and important of these are three illustrations to the story of Joseph and his brethren recounted in Genesis (Objects 20, 22, 23). These were exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1785. One year earlier, Blake’s A Breach in a City, the Morning after the Battle (object 19), had appeared at the same venue. Blake was trying, by the mid-1780s, to establish his reputation as a “history” painter—that is, as a specialist in themes taken from history, the Bible, and canonical literary texts such as Milton’s Paradise Lost. In the eighteenth century, such subjects were believed to be appropriate for the greatest artistic ambitions, but all of Blake’s exhibited works were in water colors rather than the more highly regarded medium of oil painting. Almost all of Blake’s water colors fit comfortably within the long tradition of water color drawing, in which one delineates form by line and the tinting is confined within firm outlines. Water color painting, a style developed by artists such as J. M. W. Turner, allowed for a freer use of washes, unconfined by pen and ink or pencil boundaries and without underlying washes laid in for modeling.

objtitle.title: Countess Aveline, Three Details from Her Tomb

objdescid.compdate: c. 1775This monument was uncovered in the presbytery of Westminster Abbey in the summer of 1775 and was covered again in 1778. Blake probably drew this design shortly after the monument was revealed.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its engraving for Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, first published by the Society of Antiquaries in 1780.

desc.objtitle:
Countess Aveline, Three Details from Her Tomb,
Object 1 (Butlin 5)

objnote.p: The collection stamp of the Society of Antiquaries appears lower left just inside the framing lines. A water color replica (Butlin 14) of this water color is in the Bodleian Library, Oxford. An engraving of this design was published in Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, Plate 3 (1780), and in *Vetusta Monumenta*, volume 2 of c. 1789, Plate 31.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Neatly spaced and surrounded by a fine, triple border are drawings of three details from the Countess Aveline's tomb. All three represent decorations to the tomb's canopy, and they are labeled "A," "B," and "C." Drawing "A" represents the vaulting under one side of the tomb's canopy. Three decorative capitals form the foundation of the vault. A vertical fluted pillar rises from the leftmost capital; two similar fluted pillars extend upward from the middle and rightmost capitals and meet in an arch at the design's top center. A decorative topper joins the arching pillars, and a smaller arch is visible within this larger one. The top and right sides of the design are enclosed by a border line, and the spaces between the two arches and on either side of the main arch are filled with curling vines that bear ivy leaves and possibly fruit or berries. Drawing "B" shows a detail of a trefoil on the tomb canopy. The trefoil is missing part of its top third and has three lines, perhaps suggesting cracks, emanating from the center. It has a decorative stone(?) border around an image of two female figures, perhaps angels(?). The figures kneel or sit and lean toward one another. A fire appears above and between their heads, and two fleur de lis appear at right. Drawing "C" depicts a gold acanthus bloom with a brown center and some orange coloring on its irregular petals. A pencil inscription below the designs explains their location on the Countess's tomb.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the penciled letter "A." is a drawing of the vaulting under one side of the canopy on the Countess of Aveline's tomb in Westminster Abbey. From three decorative capitals extend upward three large and two small pieces of vaulting. The left two capitals touch in the lower left corner of the design, and the third anchors the other side of the arch at right. Straight upward from the leftmost base extends a fluted pillar. Similar fluted pillars rise from the other two capitals and meet in a vaulted arch at the top of the design, culminating in a round topper whose decorative design somewhat resembles the design of the capitals. Also extending from the right two capitals, inside the arching pillars, are two shorter pillars that form a smaller, lower arch.
The top and right sides of the tomb canopy design are enclosed by a border line.

From the apex of the smaller arch in the tomb canopy design, a curling vine extends upward and fills the space within the larger arch. The vine bears leaves, possible of ivy, and may bear some sort of berries or fruit. Similar leaved, possibly fruited vines fill the spaces between the arch and the far-left pillar on one side, and between the arch and the border at right.

Right of the penciled letter "B." is a detail of a trefoil on the tomb canopy. Three lines, perhaps suggesting cracks, radiate from the center and divide the image into thirds. A substantial portion of the top section is missing. A decorative stone(?) border outlines the trefoil. The thicker outer portion of this border displays a segmented, rectangular pattern, which is repeated on the thinner interior portion of the border.

The design inside the trefoil shows two nearly identical female figures, perhaps angels(?), who sit or kneel and lean toward one another in the center of the trefoil. Both have short, curly hair and appear to look at each other. They are gowned or perhaps wear skirts and shirts. The figure on the left, who leans and faces right, may have a wing extending left from her right shoulder. Her arms may be bent upward(?) and she may smile.

The design inside the trefoil shows two nearly identical female figures, perhaps angels, who sit or kneel and lean toward one another in the center of the trefoil. Both have short, curly hair and appear to look at each other. They are gowned or perhaps wear skirts and shirts. The figure at right, who is slightly smaller and without wings, leans and faces forward and left. Her arms are bent upward and she appears to clasp her hands together.

In the trefoil design above the two figures (between their heads) is an area of red that suggests flames. Toward the outside of each lower section of the trefoil is a dark area of shadow behind each figure. In the lower half of the shadowy area at right are two fleur-de-lis.

Right of the penciled letter "C." is a drawing of an gold acanthus bloom that appears on the front of the tomb's canopy. Petals of varying length radiate from the flower's darker, brownish center. A ring of orange colors the petals about halfway between the center and their tips. At lower left is one darkened petal, or perhaps a leaf.

lg.l: A. B.This inscription and line 2 are in pencil. They are probably not by Blake.
B del."B" (with a loop over the left side and top of the letter) is the surname initial of Blake's engraving master, James Basire. This inscription was probably not written by Blake.

Vol. II. pl. 31" is a reference to volume 2 of *Vetusta Monumenta*, published by the Society of Antiquaries c. 1789. An engraving that included this design, signed by Blake's engraving master James Basire, was published as plate 31 in that volume.
